location: Vietnam (Tonkin, Red River Delta, and northern regions)

causes: The overthrow of the Lê dynasty by Mạc Đăng Dung in 1527.
Lê loyalists sought to restore their rule, supported by the Trịnh and Nguyễn clans.
Conflicts over legitimacy and control of Vietnam's northern region.
events_leading_up_to_war: Mạc Đăng Dung declared himself emperor in 1527, forcing Lê rulers into exile.
In 1533, Lê loyalists, led by Trịnh Kiểm, declared Lê Trang Tông as emperor and launched a military campaign.

result.general: Lê dynasty restored, but Vietnam remained divided.

treaties.name: Final Campaign of 1592
terms: Lê forces retook Thăng Long (Hanoi), marking the end of Mạc rule.
Mạc remnants retreated to Cao Bằng, where they held out under Chinese protection until 1677.

territorial_changes: Lê dynasty regained control of northern Vietnam.
Mạc forces confined to border regions under Ming China's influence.

entities: Noble families loyal to Mạc rule

Mac_Dynasty: Mạc Đăng Dung (Founder of Mạc rule)
Mạc Mậu Hợp (Last major Mạc ruler)
Mạc Kính Cung (Leader of later Mạc resistance)

Le_Dynasty.navy: Riverine fleets for Red River battles
Le_Dynasty.tactics: Guerrilla warfare, sieges, and naval engagements

Mac_Dynasty.navy: Strong control of northern river routes

Le_Dynasty.dead_and_wounded: Tens of thousands, prolonged warfare weakened the economy

Mac_Dynasty.dead_and_wounded: Severe losses in final battles, destruction of their capital

major_battles.name: Battle of Thăng Long
major_battles.description: Lê-Trịnh forces besieged and captured the Mạc capital of Thăng Long (Hanoi), forcing Mạc rulers to flee.

major_battles.name: Siege of Cao Bằng
major_battles.description: Mạc loyalists held out in northern Cao Bằng province with Ming China's backing.
major_battles.outcome: Gradual Lê victory, with the Mạc finally eradicated in 1677.

texts.name: Lê Dynasty Chronicles
texts.author: Lê Historians
texts.details: Documents the war from the Lê perspective, emphasizing Mạc illegitimacy.

texts.name: Mạc Family Annals
texts.author: Surviving Mạc historians
texts.details: Presents the Mạc as reformists overthrown by feudal factions.

archaeological_evidence.description: Weapons, fortifications, and burial sites in Thăng Long and Cao Bằng.
Lê royal decrees legitimizing their restoration, preserved in temple archives.

political: Lê dynasty restored, but power shifted to the Trịnh lords.
Vietnam entered a period of divided rule between the Trịnh in the north and Nguyễn in the south.
long_term_effects: Set the stage for the later Trịnh–Nguyễn War (1627–1673).
Weakened Vietnamese resistance against future Chinese and Western influences.

military: Demonstrated the effectiveness of guerrilla tactics and regional alliances.
Influenced later conflicts, such as the Tây Sơn Rebellion (18th century).
political: Marked a shift in power dynamics, with real authority moving from emperors to warlords.
Contributed to the later Nguyễn unification of Vietnam in 1802.
cultural: Shaped Vietnamese folklore, portraying the Mạc as usurpers and the Lê as rightful rulers.
Affected historical narratives, with conflicting accounts from different dynastic records.
